message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the mammogram findings suggest sclerosing adenosis. Infiltrating ductal carcinoma would show a palpable mass, skin changes, and abnormality in the physical examination. Fibroadenoma would appear as a solid mass on the mammogram, and ductal hyperplasia without atypia would not show microcalcifications with a radiolucent center.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and mammogram findings are suggestive of sclerosing adenosis, which is a benign breast disease characterized by an overgrowth of epithelial and myoepithelial cells. Fibroadenoma presents as a palpable mass. Infiltrating ductal carcinoma presents as an abnormality on physical exam and mammogram. Ductal hyperplasia without atypia does not typically present with pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, mammogram findings, and biopsy results suggest the most likely diagnosis is sclerosing adenosis. Fibroadenomas usually have a well-defined mass, infiltrating ductal carcinoma usually presents as an irregular mass with microcalcifications, and ductal hyperplasia without atypia usually presents with a palpable mass or microcalcifications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pain that worsens during menstrual cycle and relieves afterwards, along with the mammogram showing cluster of microcalcifications with radiolucent center and biopsy revealing lobulocentric proliferation of epithelium and myoepithelium, suggest sclerosing adenosis. Fibroadenoma will have a palpable mass, infiltrating ductal carcinoma will have a palpable mass and biopsy showing malignant cells, and ductal hyperplasia without atypia will not have microcalcifications or lobulocentric proliferation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history suggests cyclic pain and the mammogram shows a cluster of microcalcifications with a radiolucent center, which is a typical finding in sclerosing adenosis. The biopsy also reveals a lobulocentric proliferation of epithelium and myoepithelium, which is commonly seen in sclerosing adenosis. Fibroadenoma usually presents as a palpable, well-circumscribed mass, and it does not usually cause cyclic pain. Infiltrating ductal carcinoma typically presents as a palpable mass and is not associated with microcalcifications. Ductal hyperplasia without atypia does not typically cause microcalcifications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and mammogram results suggest Sclerosing adenosis. Infiltrating ductal carcinoma will show a palpable mass and abnormal physical examination. Fibroadenoma will show a well-circumscribed mass. Ductal hyperplasia without atypia will not show microcalcifications on mammogram.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and mammogram findings suggest sclerosing adenosis, which is a benign breast condition that can cause pain and microcalcifications on mammogram. The biopsy findings also support this diagnosis as it shows a proliferation of both epithelium and myoepithelium. Fibroadenoma usually presents as a palpable mass in the breast, infiltrating ductal carcinoma typically has more aggressive histological features, and ductal hyperplasia without atypia would not cause microcalcifications on mammogram.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pain worsening during the menstrual cycle and relieving afterwards, along with the mammogram findings of a cluster of microcalcifications with a radiolucent center, suggest the most likely diagnosis is sclerosing adenosis. Fibroadenoma would present as a palpable mass. Infiltrating ductal carcinoma and ductal hyperplasia without atypia would display different histological features on the biopsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest cyclic breast pain, and the mammogram findings suggest sclerosing adenosis. This condition can cause breast pain and is not associated with a palpable mass or skin changes. The biopsy results confirm this diagnosis as well. Fibroadenoma and infiltrating ductal carcinoma are associated with a palpable mass. Ductal hyperplasia without atypia does not cause microcalcifications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pain worsening during her menstrual cycle and the mammogram findings of microcalcifications with a radiolucent center suggest sclerosing adenosis. Fibroadenoma usually presents as a smooth, mobile, and well-circumscribed lump, without pain. Infiltrating ductal carcinoma is usually manifested by a single mass, which could be painful or not, and does not present with microcalcifications. Ductal hyperplasia without atypia usually does not cause pain and presents with a palpable mass.
